title: Memory Enhancement Phase 2: Cognitive Science Patterns
description:
Apply cognitive science research from pdf-brain to improve memory system.

## Research Sources (359 documents indexed)
- Forgetting Curve & Spaced Repetition (CodingCareer, 978-3-031-74661-1)
- Schema Acquisition & Reflective Expertise (Training_Complex_Cognitive_Skills)
- Tacit vs Explicit Knowledge (Nonaka/Takeuchi via Reframing Business)
- Cognitive Load & Chunking (Kirschner, ten-steps-to-complex-learning)
- Knowledge Organization (How Learning Works)
- Worked Examples (Multimediabook, e-Learning and the Science of Instruction)
- Interleaving & Varied Practice (Range - David Epstein)
- Metacognition & Self-Regulation (9853, Upgrade Your Teaching)
- Self-Explanation Prompts (e-Learning and the Science of Instruction)
- Second Brain / Zettelkasten (Tiago Forte, Sönke Ahrens)

## Foundation (Phase 1 - DONE ✅)
- ✅ Confidence-based decay (high confidence = slower decay)
- ✅ Git-synced memories (.hive/memories.jsonl)
- ✅ Worker prompt emphasis on memory read/write

## Phase 2 Goals
Build memories that are "schemas" (transferable patterns) not "facts" (specific fixes).

## Key Research Insights

### Testing Effect (Retrieval Practice)
> "Struggling to retrieve information primes the brain for subsequent learning" - Range
- Memories queried often should decay slower (retrieval reinforcement)
- Query count is a stronger signal than validation clicks

### Interleaving > Blocked Practice
> "For knowledge to be flexible, it should be learned under varied conditions" - Range
- Mixed/varied practice leads to better transfer
- Memories should be tagged for cross-domain retrieval

### Self-Explanation Prompts
> "Self-explanation questions ask learners to explain the concepts or principles" - e-Learning
- Workers should explain WHY something works, not just WHAT
- Prompt workers to articulate the underlying principle

### Negative Examples (Counter-Examples)
> "Contrast carefully a correct demonstration with an incorrect one" - Training Complex Cognitive Skills
- Store anti-patterns alongside patterns
- "What NOT to do" is as valuable as "what to do"

### Worked Examples
> "Novice learners learn more from studying worked examples than from solving equivalent problems"
- Before/after code snippets in memories
- Show the transformation, not just the end state

### Connection Strength (Zettelkasten)
> "Note-to-note links are like weak ties - they often offer unexpected insights" - Smart Notes
- Memories that reference other memories form a graph
- Well-connected nodes should decay slower

### Tacit Knowledge
> "Tacit knowledge is difficult to articulate and of a heuristic, procedural nature"
- Low confidence = "I sense this is true but can't fully explain"
- Encourage storing intuitions with examples, not just rules

### Metacognitive Prompts
> "Metacognition includes self-regulation - the ability to plan, monitor success, and correct errors"
- Prompt workers: "Would you be able to perform this task in a new context?"
- Encourage reflection on transferability

title: Self-explanation prompts in memory storage
description:
Based on: "Self-explanation questions ask learners to explain the concepts or principles" - e-Learning and the Science of Instruction

When storing memories, prompt workers to answer:
- WHY does this work? (underlying principle)
- WHEN does this apply? (conditions for use)
- WHAT could go wrong? (edge cases)

Implementation:
- Add `principle` field to memory schema
- Update worker prompt to require self-explanation
- Memories with principles get slower decay

title: Anti-pattern storage (negative examples)
description:
Based on: "Contrast carefully a correct demonstration with an incorrect one" - Training Complex Cognitive Skills

Store what NOT to do alongside what to do:
- Add `is_antipattern` boolean field
- Link anti-patterns to their positive counterparts
- Search should surface both pattern and anti-pattern together

Example:
- Pattern: "Use Zod for sync validation"
- Anti-pattern: "AVOID: Zod refinements for async validation (blocks event loop)"

title: Metacognitive transfer prompts
description:
Based on: "Metacognition includes self-regulation - the ability to plan, monitor success, and correct errors" - 9853

Add prompts that encourage reflection on transferability:
- "Would you be able to apply this in a different context?"
- "What would need to change for this to work elsewhere?"
- "Rate your confidence that this generalizes (1-5)"

Implementation:
- Add `transferability_score` field (1-5)
- High transferability = schema, low = specific fix
- Use in search ranking (prefer transferable memories)

title: Hierarchical tagging system
description:
Based on: "Knowledge organization influences learning and performance" - How Learning Works

Current tagging is flat. Implement hierarchy:
- `auth/oauth/refresh-tokens`
- `nextjs/caching/dynamic-rendering`
- `testing/mocking/dependency-injection`

Benefits:
- Search at any level of specificity
- Auto-suggest related tags
- Better clustering in search results

Implementation:
- Parse `/` in tags as hierarchy
- Store parent tags implicitly
- Search `auth/*` matches all auth subtags

title: Spaced retrieval scheduling (Anki-style intervals)
description:
Based on: "Use spaced repetition learning. Anki is the leader here." - CodingCareer

Instead of passive decay, implement active retrieval scheduling:
- Track `last_retrieved_at` and `retrieval_count`
- Calculate optimal next retrieval interval (SM-2 algorithm variant)
- Surface "due for review" memories proactively

Benefits:
- Memories that need reinforcement get surfaced
- Prevents important memories from fading
- Builds on testing effect research

Implementation:
- Add `next_review_at` timestamp
- Coordinator prompt: "Review these memories before starting"
- Successful retrieval extends interval, failure shortens it

title: Weak-link discovery (Zettelkasten cross-references)
description:
Based on: "Note-to-note links are like weak ties - they often offer unexpected insights" - Smart Notes

Implement cross-domain memory linking:
- When storing, suggest related memories from different domains
- Track explicit links between memories
- Surface unexpected connections in search

Example:
- Memory about "OAuth token refresh timing" links to
- Memory about "database connection pool timeout"
- Both are about "resource lifecycle management"

Implementation:
- Add `related_memory_ids` array field
- Use embedding similarity to suggest links
- Bonus decay reduction for well-connected memories

title: Tacit knowledge capture (intuition storage)
description:
Based on: "Tacit knowledge is difficult to articulate and of a heuristic, procedural nature" - Training Complex Cognitive Skills

Some knowledge is hard to explain but valuable:
- "This code smells wrong but I can't say why"
- "I've seen this pattern fail before"
- "My gut says use approach A over B"

Implementation:
- Add `is_tacit` boolean field
- Tacit memories require worked examples (before/after)
- Lower confidence threshold for tacit knowledge
- Prompt: "Show an example where this intuition was correct"

Goal: Capture intuitions that would otherwise be lost, with enough context to be useful.

title: Memory chunking validation (right granularity)
description:
Based on: "Chunking is a function of our prior knowledge" - 978-3-031-74661-1

Memories should be "one transferable insight":
- Too granular = noise, hard to find
- Too broad = not actionable
- Sweet spot = one pattern per memory

Implementation:
- Add word count / complexity heuristics
- Warn if memory is too short (<50 words) or too long (>500 words)
- Suggest splitting broad memories
- Suggest merging related granular memories

Validation prompts:
- "Is this one idea or multiple?"
- "Could this be applied without additional context?"
